title: Arduino 101
description: Learn the very basics of how to program with the popular platform for physical computing projects. If you took the “Hello, Arduino” session on Monday night, this session will cover that information, but also delve deeper into the topics of digital input and output as well as analog input and output.

title: Pop-up books and paper circuits
description: Pop-up engineering is really fun and extremely satisfying – for adults and for kids. But how might we use electricity to change the idea of what “interactive” books can be? In this session, participants will create pop-up cards that use the affordances of our materials to really investigate how circuits can change the idea of what a book can be. We’ll also consider where soft circuits are going by looking at examples in toys and wearable technologies.

title: Shop Safety!
description: Get Shop certified!

title: exploring biomimicry
description: This 2-hour workshop on biomimicry will address nature as inspiration for design and technological solutions. We will consider the biological and natural world, and work hands on to create quick prototypes using paper, pen, and some building materials, on topics that might include re-designing social networks, mapping urban spaces, and re-defining user interfaces.

title: Introduction to User Experience (UX)
description: What is User Experience?

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple’s native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the “Hello World” stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We’ll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time.

title: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium
description: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium is the first installment of a 3 part series on creating narratives within in the framework of a app. This lecture is a survey of current artists and projects using the mobile platform to create innovative narrative forms (i.e: Christoph Niemann’s “Petting Zoo”,  David Benqué’s “The Infinite Adventure Machine”, Works from “Les Editions Volumiques” etc…).

title: Product Design/DigiFab
description: We will be covering design tools (software and hardware) for digital fabrication.

title: ITP Mappathon: Content Making for Projection Mapping
description:
Step 1
 This week, we will learn how to make visual content using Modul8.
 We will use a png, a jpg and a movie files to make a moving image using Modul8. This method is a great tool to camp your idea.

title: the beauty of ephemeral life
description: A talk about my work in recent and past.

title: Introduction to Soft Circuits
description: In this class, we will go over conductive materials used in creating soft circuits, such as different thread, fabrics, inks and fasteners, along with looking at microcontrollers designed specifically for wearable electronics. Projects that have been created utilizing these techniques will also be shown. We will then create a simple soft circuit with a switch and that lights up a LED. Attendees will have the chance to learn or expand on basic hand sewing techniques and experience working with new materials and skills.

title: Acrylic Cutting and Bending
description: Learn a fast and easy way to prototype precision parts using the laser cutter.  And then literally take it in a new direction with the acrylic bender.  Quickly turn 2D parts into 3 dimensional objects.

title: AT&T AdWorks Lab Tour
description: I’ll give a quick and informal tour of the AdWorks Media Lab.  We’ll look at how we used Cinder to create some very cool (at least we think so!) data visualizations and explain how we developed the narrative for the entire space.  You can see the pool table that will soon be transformed into a completely, interactive experience!    Lastly, you’ll also get a sneak peek at the redesign that we’re currently doing that will launch in September.

title: Quantified Self: Tools, Trends, and Applications
description: When Forbes called 2013 “the year of the Quantified Self” at CES it became clear that this is no longer a niche field just for life loggers. In this session I will go through the history of the quantified self (QS) movement, the existing apps/devices available, ways to hack together your own tools, trends in the industry, and discuss areas that are still untouched by this phenomenon that seems to be the new buzz word of 2013. A year and a half ago my life changed when I began tracking what I ate and how I felt, eventually leading me to cut gluten and dairy out of my diet. Since then I have become immersed in the QS field, helping to co-organize numerous Quantified Self Meetups here in NY, experimenting with dozens of QS tools/apps, and hacking together numerous quantified self tools of my own and in groups with others. By the end of this session participants should have a thorough understanding of the existing QS landscape, be aware of industries ripe for QS development, and be primed with some easy ways to hack together their own projects and tools.

title: Sensing our surroundings : log sensor data using arduino
description: This hands on workshop will address visualizing data input from Arduino. The context of the class will be based around open source semi-autonomous sailing robots called Protei, designed to sense & clean oceans. After a brief introduction about Protei project, the remainder of the session will be devoted to understanding the very basics of sensing & exploring the environment through collecting & visualizing data using remote sensors, including sensors such as photocells, potentiometers, and more complex ones like barometers, GPS, and accelerometers.

title: What the Glyph? Finding and Using Fonts for Your Projects
description: What’s a font? What’s a typeface? Why would you spend good money on buying a font when there are so many of them floating around for free?

title: Hacking Higher Ed
description: Exciting innovation is happening in the area of higher education. This session will ask participants to look at ways to reinvent higher education to increase its accessibility and exceed the current quality of the experience. We will do a brief survey current experiments such as Udacity, Khan Academic, O’Reilly, Code Academy, Meetups, TED Talks, General Assembly, Hackerspaces.   Topics will talk about new way of thinking about Curriculum, Content,  Conversation, Motivations and Outcomes,  Community,  Physical Space,  Economics, Research to create new institutions for higher education.  These topics are based on the syllabus for this course http://itp.nyu.edu/~dbo3/hack-ed/

title: ITP Mappathon: Projection Mapping with MadMapper
description:
Step 2
 This week, we will learn how to connect your visual content created from Modul8 to a projection mapping software, MadMapper.

title: Experiment Design Workshop
description: Designing a proper experiment is not a trivial task: and the questions to ask are dependent on your field of study.  In this workshop we will discuss the design of usability studies and scientific studies, and how to use science to get at the truth of the matter your interested in

title: Arduino Programming Basics
description: So if you want to move beyond the blinking LED and learn some more coding for the Arduino, this is the class for you. We’ll review some of the coding from Arduino 101 and then move onto variables, for loops, while loops, and writing your own functions.

title: Turning on the lathe
description: **YOU MUST HAVE HAD A SHOP SAFETY TRAINING IN ORDER TO TAKE THIS CLASS.  NO EXCEPTIONS.**

title: “Noticing” Workshop
description: This workshop teaches techniques and tools for noticing—seeing, hearing and comprehending something new. In a short series of exercises we’ll explore the observation process in an array of domains, from cognitive psychology to ethnography and drawing to data collection, with techniques for reaching that moment we all crave: when something unexpected and terrific bursts forward into consciousness. Participants will leave with their eyes wide open to the inspirations and complexity that surround us all and their minds full of techniques for learning more.

title: 3D Scanning Workshop with the Kinect & ReconstructMe
description: We’ll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models. I have built a rig for doing full body human scans. The rig builds on this turntable I built last year: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28454 We’ll cover my scanning technique then a workflow for taking scans to a printable mesh using Netfabb Basic. I can also touch on some tricks with Meshlab if we need to combine meshes, remesh or reduce polygon count.

title: 3D Scanning Workshop with the Kinect & ReconstructMe
description: We’ll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models. I have built a rig for doing full body human scans. The rig builds on this turntable I built last year: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28454 We’ll cover my scanning technique then a workflow for taking scans to a printable mesh using Netfabb Basic. I can also touch on some tricks with Meshlab if we need to combine meshes, remesh or reduce polygon count.

title: Data Visualization with Processing!
description: coming!

title: Rest Of You: Digital Edition
description: Life is what happens to you will you are busy doing other things.  You pay attention to a small part of your experience when it is the rest of you that is more important.  The Rest of You is a class about trying to get a better picture of those parts that you don’t pay attention to.  This session will zero in on one week of work in the Rest Of You class that tries to cull through your digital footprint to give you a more accurate picture of yourself and perhaps suggest some interventions to change the rest of you.    Here are some assignments from the digital week of this class http://itp.nyu.edu/~dbo3/roy/?cat=12

title: ITP Thesis Spotlight
From Story to Tech: a methodology project
description: Often times, it seems that tech projects can come off as nothing more than technological masturbation. Many of us know what it’s like to witness a new project with cutting-edge tech only to feel disappointed, likening the experience more to a technical demo than something poignant and worth remembering. This may happen with projects of any nature, of course, but tech projects are especially prone to the pitfall of gadgetry taking precedence over meaning.

title: Guest Speaker: Clive Thompson – “the new literacies”
Now What?! How to turn your prototype into a product
description: When individuals and companies want to bring their product to the market, they run into hurdles like how to source materials, how to access a group of people who will buy it, and how to do it in a way that it doesn’t eat up all their savings and free time. This session is a crash course in the commercialization arc that includes product development, validation, and commercial ramp up.  Issues that arise in these post-prototype stages are important design insights that will make your product idea stronger. We’ll get into practical examples of how to connect with funding sources, user communities, and manufacturers while sharing resources that’ll be ready and waiting once camp is over.

title: Jitter Workshop: Coding for Video Art
Designing Interactive Experiences for Public Spaces
How to Teach Yourself How to Code
description: Led by a person still learning how to code, this session-discussion will explore methods for teaching yourself how to code. I’ve been a bit dissatisfied with the resources currently available, and aim to develop a workshop presenting a framework of tools to scaffold self-teaching for those without a STEM background.

title: Tom Igoe Mystery Talk
Really Big Video Part 2
description: In this session, campers will compile and project their work from the previous week onto a giant building on broadway using video mapping and one really big projector. Taught by Gabe BC
